fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:description: SVG is a language for describing two-dimensional graphics in XML. The XML DTD for SVG (version 1.x) allows for three types of graphic objects: vector graphic shapes (e.g., paths consisting of straight lines and curves), raster graphics (raster images), and text. Graphical objects can be grouped, styled, transformed and composited into previously rendered objects. The feature set includes nested transformations, clipping paths, alpha masks, filter effects and template objects. SVG may also be used for animations; see Notes below.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: SVG is a language for describing two-dimensional graphics in XML. SVG allows for three types of graphic objects: vector graphic shapes (e.g., paths consisting of straight lines and curves), raster graphics (raster images), and text.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG), Version 1.0 (2001), not described at this Web site.

Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG), Version 2. This update is under development. As of March 2020, a W3C Candidate Recommendation, issued October 4, 2018, is available at http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/. The most recent editor's draft can be found at https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/. Not described at this website at this time. Work on a Version 1.2 of the full SVG standard has been abandoned.
SVG Profile intended for implementation on a range of devices, including cellphones and PDAs as well as laptops and personal computers.
Two reduced profiles of SVG 1.1 for mobile devices: SVG Basic 1.1 and SVG Tiny 1.1, not described separately at this website.
EPUB_2 readers are required to recognize and display embedded SVG images.
EPUB_3 uses a restricted subset of SVG 1.1 to represent inline vector graphics in documents based on XHTML and in standalone SVG-based EPUBs.

fdd:relatedTo.fdd:titleName: OpenDocument Format (ODF) Family, OASIS and ISO/IEC 26300

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: ODF uses the svg: prefix for elements and attributes compatible with SVG 1.1.

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: The Library of Congress Recommended Formats Statement (RFS) includes SVG as a preferred format for other graphic images in digital form. The RFS does not specify a version of SVG.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) 1.1 (Second Edition). SVG_1_1 was originally published in 2003. The Second Edition includes clarificatons and corrections for errata but no new features, released on August 16, 2011.

fdd:adoption.p: Many enthusiastic users and groups; see Useful references below. SVG is supported in Adobe tools, Visio (Microsoft), Corel Draw 11, and as an export format by ESRI ArcGIS. There are several open source applications and software libraries that can read and write SVG images. SVG is listed in Recommended Data Formats for Preservation Purposes in the Florida Digital Archive in the column for formats for which the archive has high confidence level for preservation. Browser support has varied with many complaints about lack of support by Internet Explorer. An infographic from late 2014 indicates that support is full in Safari, Firefox, Chrome, and Opera; support in IE started with IE 9 and support in Android with version 4. A more detailed presentation of SVG feature support is available from caniuse.com. A feature support comparison is also available at Comparison of layout engines (Scalable Vector Graphics) on Wikipedia. However the Wikipedia table may not have been kept up to date. Testing SVG support across browser engines explores support by the engines used in various browsers on a test SVG file. What these tables and tests suggest is that some features are less widely supported than others. Support for ICC profiles and some font-related capabilities may be examples of less widely supported features. In some contexts, animations and audio are not rendered.

The October 2011 EPUB_3 specification for Electronic Publications uses a restricted subset of SVG_1_1 as a content document format for graphics, including use as a top-level format for comics and graphic novels. Not supported in EPUB_3 are animations and embedding of "foreign objects" in forms other than XHTML.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:licensingAndPatents: No special issues. As of January 2004, the SVG Working Group was not aware of any royalty-bearing patents they believe to be essential to SVG.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Based on XML, hence inherently transparent.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation: Includes <metadata> element designed to hold elements from other XML namespaces. Hence an SVG file can contain rich descriptive or administrative metadata using any other DTD.

fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:clarity: Scalable. Optional settings for rendering hints: crispEdges and geometricPrecision.
fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:colorMaint: SVG colors are specified in the sRGB color space. SVG content can specify an alternate color specification using a profile as defined by the International Color Consortium (ICC). See the ICC Profile Format Specification. ICC.1:2004-10. If ICC-based colors are provided and the SVG user agent supports ICC color, then the ICC-based color takes precedence over the sRGB color specification.
fdd:stillImageQF.fdd:beyondImage: Support for animations. Text in alternate languages for labels, etc.

fdd:general.p: Animations in SVG: SVG markup can be used to present animations on the web in several ways: including using SVG's animation elements, using CSS, or by scripting. The Wikipedia entry for SVG animation offers a number of examples using different approaches.

In 2013, most web sites presented simple animations as GIF_89a files and more complex animations and interactives as Flash SWF_7 or SWF_8 files (or later versions). Commentators with an interest in animation, including advocates for SVG as a publicly disclosed format, compared SVG and SWF but noted that the powerful authoring software available for Flash gave SWF the edge. Since then, the Flash plugin has been recognized as a persistent security risk and HTML 5 has provided other means for embedding video in web pages. See Thoughts on Flash from Wikipedia entry for HTML5. In early 2020, animated GIFs are still very popular on the web, including for advertising. The compilers of this resource have not attemped to determine whether SVG animations are used more widely now that most browsers support them. Comments welcome.

fdd:history.p: SVG was originally developed through a process that began in 1996, with a call for responses to W3C Scalable Graphics Requirements. According to Secret Origin of SVG, there were six proposals submitted by 1998, and SVG was particularly influenced by VML (Vector Markup Language), already deployed in Microsoft products, and PGML, a proposal from a partnership led by Adobe and using the same imaging model as in Postscript and PDF.

Version 2 of SVG has been under development for several years. As of March 2020, a W3C Candidate Recommendation, issued October 4, 2018, is available at http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/. The most recent editor's draft can be found at https://svgwg.org/svg2-draft/. See also SVG2 Requirements Input.

fdd:urlReference.comment: Enthusiast site. Active page not found on February 8, 2012; many pages archived by the Internet Archive, including this 2010 example.

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: LearnSVG (offline as of early 2020) was a site with links to tutorials and other resources related to SVG. The initial site (first archived by the Internet Archive in 2003) was based on the content of the book "Learn SVG – The Web Graphics Standard" by Jon Frost, Stefan Goessner and Michel Hirtzler.

fdd:urlReference.comment: Has outline and extracts of chapters from the LearnSVG book.
The front page was now a rich menu of links to resources related to SVG.

Website (with content in English and German) devoted to cartography. This section (no longer maintained) focused on the use of SVG for mapping applications.

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: Adobe Systems has been actively involved in the development of SVG and supports SVG in several products.
